meanings.sent1: The new technology will revolutionise how we communicate with each other.
meanings.sent2: The invention of the telephone revolutionised long-distance communication.
meanings.sent3: Trying to revolutionise the way we tie our shoes might be a bit extreme.
meanings.sent4: Her innovative idea could revolutionise the entire industry overnight.
meanings.sent5: The young entrepreneur aimed to revolutionise the market with her unique product.

meanings.definition: To bring about a radical change in something.
meanings.sent1: The unexpected discovery would revolutionise the field of science.
meanings.sent2: The protest aimed to revolutionise the outdated policies of the government.
meanings.sent3: His plan to revolutionise the way we eat breakfast was met with laughter.
meanings.sent4: The artist's bold strokes seemed to revolutionise the canvas before our eyes.
meanings.sent5: The groundbreaking research could revolutionise the medical world as we know it.

meanings.definition: To transform or modernize a process or system.
meanings.sent1: The new software will revolutionise how we manage our finances.
meanings.sent2: The introduction of automation revolutionised the manufacturing industry.
meanings.sent3: Attempting to revolutionise the way we do laundry might be a messy experiment.
meanings.sent4: Her creative approach could revolutionise the traditional way of teaching.
meanings.sent5: The company's decision to revolutionise their marketing strategy paid off handsomely.
